title: 114_hr1329
content:
The ATF Elimination Act rescinds the hiring authority of the Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives. Within 180 days of enactment, ATF, FBI, and DEA directors must develop a plan to wind up ATF affairs, reducing unnecessary functions. FBI must report excess property to be transferred within a year. The Director has determined the property to be transferred to the Bureau pursuant to this Act that will not be needed by the Bureau. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives is abolished. Functions related to federal firearms, explosives, arson laws, violent crime, and domestic terrorism are transferred to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The functions related to investigating and enforcing criminal and regulatory violations of federal firearms, explosives, and arson laws, as well as investigating violent crime and domestic terrorism, previously handled by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives, are now under the jurisdiction of the Attorney General. The Attorney General will delegate these functions to the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Any references to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives in other federal laws or documents now refer to the Attorney General. The Attorney General now handles functions related to investigating and enforcing federal firearms, explosives, and arson laws, as well as investigating violent crime and domestic terrorism. References to specific bureaus in federal laws now refer to the appropriate agencies such as the Department of Justice or the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Transfer of functions related to federal alcohol and tobacco smuggling laws to the Drug Enforcement Administration. The functions related to investigating and enforcing criminal and regulatory violations of federal alcohol and tobacco smuggling laws are transferred from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives to the Attorney General. The Attorney General will delegate these functions to the Administrator of Drug Enforcement. References to the transferred functions in other federal laws and documents now refer to the Attorney General. References to the Department of the Treasury or related bureau now refer to the Department of Justice or the Drug Enforcement Administration. SEC. 7. PROPERTY AND RECORDS: Contracts, liabilities, records, property, and assets related to transferred functions are allocated to the Attorney General.

SEC. 8. PERSONNEL: Personnel connected to transferred functions are moved to the Attorney General without reduction in grade or compensation for a year.

SEC. 9. SAVINGS PROVISIONS: Savings provisions are in place. All legal documents issued by various government officials in relation to transferred functions will remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials in accordance with the law. The provisions of this Act do not affect pending proceedings or applications for benefits, services, licenses, permits, certificates, or financial assistance before the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives. Orders issued in such proceedings will continue until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by law. The Act does not impact ongoing proceedings or applications before the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives. Any suits, actions, or proceedings involving the bureau or its officers will continue unaffected by the Act's enactment. Under this Act, if any agency or officer is involved in a lawsuit and their functions are transferred to the Attorney General or another Department of Justice official, the suit will continue with the new official substituted or added as a party. SEC. 10. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments to the Homeland Security Act of 2002 include transferring the Personnel Management Demonstration Project to the Secretary of the Treasury and changing references from "Bureau" to "Federal Bureau of Investigation." Amendments to various acts include changes to the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act of 2002, the Firefighters' Safety Study Act, and Title 18 of the United States Code. These changes involve redesignating subparagraphs, amending sections, and removing certain provisions. Amendments to the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act involve changes to the disclosure of firearms trace data by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Amendments to the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act involve replacing "Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives" with "Federal Bureau of Investigation" in certain provisions. Amendments to the Omnibus Appropriations Act, 2009 and Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2008 involve replacing "Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives" with "Federal Bureau of Investigation" in specific provisions. Amendments in various appropriations acts involve replacing "Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives" with "Federal Bureau of Investigation" in specific provisions. Amendments in appropriations acts replace "Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives" with "Federal Bureau of Investigation" in specific provisions of the United States Code. Amendments replace "Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives" with "Federal Bureau of Investigation" in specific provisions of the United States Code. Subsection (a) is amended to replace special agents with any, and subsection (b) is struck. Section 3051 in the table of sections for chapter 203 of title 18, United States Code, is also amended. Amendments are made to various laws, including the National Drug Control Policy Reauthorization Act of 1998 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, replacing references to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Additionally, changes are made to Title 28 of the United States Code. Amendments are made to Title 28 and Title 31 of the United States Code, including repealing Chapter 40A and making changes to various sections. Additionally, amendments are made to the Violence Against Women and Department of Justice Reauthorization Act of 2005. Amendments are made to Title 31, United States Code, including changes to Section 713 regarding the Service and Tax and Trade Bureau. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include changes to Section 713 regarding the Tax and Trade Bureau, Department of the Treasury. Amendments were made to various laws including the Justice Assistance Act of 1984, the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994, and Title 49 of the United States Code. These changes involved removing references to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives and replacing them with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Amendment to Title 49, United States Code involves replacing references to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives with the Drug Enforcement Administration. The Act and its amendments, excluding sections 2 and 3, will take effect one year after enactment.
